channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2018 The New York Times Company

item.title: Nature Cursed Indonesia, but It Took Neglect to Make a Disaster
item.media:description: The remains of the Petobo neighborhood in Palu, Indonesia. Despite earthquake after earthquake hitting Palu over the years, the 7.5 magnitude quake last month caught officials unprepared.
item.media:credit: Adam Dean for The New York Times
item.description: As the city of Palu mourns the dead from an earthquake and tsunami, it is haunted by questions of whether the government could have stemmed the devastation.
item.dc:creator: HANNAH BEECH and MUKTITA SUHARTONO

item.title: Canada Is Legalizing Cannabis. Here’s What You Need to Know.
item.media:description: This year’s annual marijuana rally on Parliament Hill in Ottawa, Ontario.
item.description: As Canada prepares to become only the second country in the world, besides Uruguay, to legalize marijuana, the country is scrambling to get ready.
item.dc:creator: IAN AUSTEN, CATHERINE PORTER and DAN BILEFSKY

item.title: U.K.’s ‘Brexit Preppers’ Stock Up on Supplies, Preparing for E.U. Exit
item.media:description: Nevine and Richard Mann have started planting crops in their garden in Cornwall, England, in case Britain’s departure from the European Union disrupts food supplies.
item.media:credit: James Beck for The New York Times
item.description: Some people are warning of possible food rationing, medicine shortages and civil disorder if no deal is struck with the European Union. Brexit supporters call that fear-mongering.
item.dc:creator: STEPHEN CASTLE

item.title: Pompeo Meets With Saudi Leaders to Discuss Khashoggi Case
item.media:description: Protesters holding pictures of the missing journalist Jamal Khashoggi outside the Saudi Consulate in Istanbul this month.
item.description: The secretary of state met with top officials in Riyadh amid international outrage over the reported killing of Mr. Khashoggi, a critic of the Saudi leadership.
item.dc:creator: BEN HUBBARD and DANIEL VICTOR

item.title: News Analysis: As Voters on Left and Right Rebel, Glimpse of a Post-Merkel Germany
item.media:description: Chancellor Angela Merkel at a news conference last month in Berlin.
item.description: An election in Bavaria was expected to turn on a populist backlash against migrants, but voters went their own way. The results may worry Angela Merkel, but analysts say they signal a healthy democracy.
item.dc:creator: KATRIN BENNHOLD and MELISSA EDDY
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis

item.title: Talks Begin on Disarming Korean Border Village
item.media:description: Ri Son-gwon, the North Korean official in charge of unification, crossing the border in the truce village of Panmunjom on Monday to attend a meeting with Cho Myoung-gyon, his South Korean counterpart.
item.description: The United Nations Command and representatives from both Koreas will discuss erasing the demarcation line at Panmunjom, officials said, as a way to improve ties.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN
item.category: Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament

item.title: China Breaks Silence on Muslim Detention Camps, Calling Them ‘Humane’
item.media:description: Security personnel near the Id Kah Mosque in Kashgar, in the Xinjiang region of China. Hundreds of thousands of Muslims in Xinjiang have been held in a network of indoctrination camps.
item.description: A senior official defended the vast detention network in the Xinjiang region, calling it a “vocational education and training program.”
item.dc:creator: CHRIS BUCKLEY
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: 2 Myanmar Fighter Jets Crash, Killing Pilots and an 11-Year-Old
item.media:description: The wreckage of a Myanmar Air Force F-7 fighter jet after it crashed near the city of Saklu on Tuesday.
item.description: It was the latest in a string of accidents for one of Asia’s largest militaries, which has rapidly expanded its arsenal.
item.dc:creator: HANNAH BEECH and SAW NANG

item.title: Harry and Meghan Charm Sometimes Skeptical Subjects in Australia
item.media:description: Prince Harry and his wife Meghan, the duchess of Sussex, at the Sydney Opera House on Tuesday.
item.media:credit: Joel Carrett/Australian Associated Press, via Reuters
item.description: What is the relationship, both political and emotional, between Australia and the royal family?
item.dc:creator: ISABELLA KWAI

item.title: Google to Charge Phone Makers for Android Apps in Europe
item.media:description: Samsung unveiled its Galaxy Note 9 handset in Brooklyn in August. The device is one of 24,000 that use Google’s Android operating system.
item.media:credit: Timothy A. Clary/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.description: To comply with a European antitrust ruling, Google will begin charging a licensing fee of handset makers.
item.dc:creator: ADAM SATARIANO

item.title: Trump Threatens to Punish Honduras Over Immigrant Caravan
item.media:description: A caravan of as many as 2,000 mostly Honduran migrants began their march north on Friday in San Pedro Sula.
item.description: As many as 2,000 mostly Honduran migrants are in Guatemala, heading to the United States. President Trump has warned Honduras he might cut aid if the migrants do not return home.
item.dc:creator: KIRK SEMPLE

item.title: Saudis Issued Dire Warnings Against U.S. Sanctions. But How Much Leverage Do They Have?
item.media:description: A Saudi Aramco oil refinery and terminal in the eastern Saudi city Ras Tanura.
item.description: The Saudis have a powerful tool in their ability to raise oil prices but are loathe to use it. And they could not easily switch to China or Russia for defense.
item.dc:creator: CLIFFORD KRAUSS and RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: Saudi Crown Prince to Pompeo: We Are ‘Allies’
item.description: Secretary of State Mike Pompeo met with Crown Prince Mohammad Bin Salman to discuss the disappearance of the Saudi journalist Jamal Khashoggi.

item.title: Jim Mattis Says He and Trump ‘Never Talked About Me Leaving’
item.media:description: Defense Secretary Jim Mattis arriving in Ho Chi Minh City, Vietnam, on Tuesday.
item.description: The defense secretary played down suggestions he was on the outs with President Trump, who recently said of Mr. Mattis, “I think he’s sort of a Democrat.”
item.dc:creator: HELENE COOPER
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas

item.title: Chinese Internet Star Detained for ‘Disrespectful’ Version of National Anthem
item.description: Yang Kaili, a 20-year-old woman with tens of millions of followers, had sung a brief snippet of the anthem online, wearing an antler-shaped headband.
item.dc:creator: AMY QIN

item.title: Australian Leader Considers Moving Embassy to Jerusalem From Tel Aviv
item.media:description: Prime Minister Scott Morrison of Australia with Marise Payne, the foreign minister, at Parliament House in Canberra on Tuesday.
item.description: Prime Minister Scott Morrison echoed many of the points President Trump gave for a similar decision. The announcement drew criticism as a political gambit to win a local election.
item.dc:creator: JAMIE TARABAY

item.title: Nigerian Militants Kill 2nd Captive Aid Worker, Government Says
item.media:description: Hauwa Liman, in undated photograph. She was executed by the Islamist militants who had kidnapped in Nigeria, government officials said Monday night.
item.media:credit: International Committee of the Red Cross, via Reuters
item.description: A Nigerian government minister said Hauwa Liman, 24, who worked for the International Committee of the Red Cross, was killed after failed attempts to secure her release from a faction of Boko Haram.
item.dc:creator: EMMANUEL AKINWOTU
item.category: International Committee of the Red Cross

item.title: Russia Takes Further Step Toward Major Schism in Orthodox Church
item.media:description: Ecumenical Patriarch Bartholomew I, the spiritual leader of the world’s Orthodox Christians, after a Mass in Istanbul last week.
item.description: The Russian Orthodox Church moved to sever ties with the Constantinople Patriarchate to protest moves to form an independent church in Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: NEIL MacFARQUHAR

item.title: DNA, Paul Allen, Saudi Arabia: Your Monday Evening Briefing
item.description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
item.dc:creator: JEAN RUTTER and HIROKO MASUIKE

item.title: Belgium Elects Nation’s First Black Mayor, a Congolese Immigrant
item.media:description: Pierre Kompany, 71, who came to Belgium as a Congolese refugee in 1975, was elected as the nation’s first black mayor on Sunday, in a mostly white borough of Brussels.
item.description: Almost six decades after Belgium’s rule ended in Congo, a land it brutalized for decades, an overwhelmingly white borough elected a man who was born in that colony.
item.dc:creator: MILAN SCHREUER

item.title: Amid Brexit Impasse, Theresa May Says Deal Is ‘Achievable’
item.media:description: Prime Minister Theresa May of Britain this month. She said on Monday, “I do not believe the U.K. and the E.U. are far apart.”
item.description: With negotiations over Britain’s withdrawal from the European Union stymied, the British prime minister is trying to put a summit meeting back on track.
item.dc:creator: STEPHEN CASTLE and STEVEN ERLANGER

item.title: Abortion Debate in Australia Has a New Element: Women in Power
item.media:description: A rally in support of proposed changes to Queensland’s abortion laws in Brisbane, Australia, on Sunday.
item.description: The Parliament in the Australian state of Queensland, which has achieved a striking level of representation for women, is considering scrapping a century-old abortion law.
item.dc:creator: RICK ROJAS

item.title: Rescuing Sea Turtles From Fishermen’s Nets
item.media:description: A green sea turtle trapped in a gill net. Scientists estimate the global green turtle population has declined 50 to 70 percent since 1900.
item.description: An organization on the coast of Kenya tries to persuade local residents to help return the trapped reptiles to the ocean, rather than sell their meat and shells for a living.
item.dc:creator: AMY YEE

item.title: U.S. Credit Card Giants Flout India’s New Law on Personal Data
item.media:description: Visa, Mastercard and American Express will be violating a new Indian law that is going into effect on Monday night every time an Indian swipes a credit or debit card.
item.description: As India develops new rules governing the data of its residents, global firms are the first target. Companies say they need more time to comply.
item.dc:creator: VINDU GOEL

item.title: Invisible Irish Border Carries the Scars of a Fractured Past
item.media:description: The line that divides the two Irelands runs along the top of Cuilcagh Mountain.
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.description: The frontier between the Republic of Ireland and Northern Ireland has become a major sticking point in talks about Britain’s exit from the European Union.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW TESTA and MEGAN SPECIA

item.title: ‘Shocking and Abhorrent’ Abuse Rampant in U.K. Parliament, Report Says
item.media:description: John Bercow, center, the speaker of the House of Commons, in Parliament last year. “I find it difficult to envisage how the necessary changes can be successfully delivered, and the confidence of the staff restored, under the current senior House administration,” a new report says.
item.description: An inquiry into sexual harassment in the House of Commons describes a “master and servant” culture, with lawmakers accorded an “almost godlike status.”
item.dc:creator: ELLEN BARRY

item.title: French Flash Floods Kill at Least 11
item.media:description: A bridge over the Trapel River collapsed on Monday in Villegailhenc, in southern France, amid flash floods.
item.description: Torrential rains in the southwestern Aude region turned small rivers into raging torrents, flooding towns, cutting off roads and trapping people in their cars or homes.
item.dc:creator: AURELIEN BREEDEN

item.title: A Genocide Incited on Facebook, With Posts From Myanmar’s Military
item.media:description: A border police officer at a repatriation center for Rohingya returning to Myanmar. Human rights groups blame anti-Rohingya propaganda online for fueling violence and displacement.
item.media:credit: Adam Dean for The New York Times
item.description: With fake pages and sham accounts, the military targeted the mostly Muslim Rohingya minority group, said former military officials, researchers and civilian officials.
item.dc:creator: PAUL MOZUR
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity

item.title: Syria Reopens Border Link to Jordan, as Assad Reasserts Control
item.media:description: Vehicles on the Jordanian side of the border waiting to enter Syria at the Nassib crossing point on Monday.
item.description: Syrian officials celebrated the reopening of the crossing with Jordan, hoping it would foster trade and lead to normalization with other Arab states.
item.dc:creator: RANA F. SWEIS and BEN HUBBARD

item.title: What Canada Can Learn from California on Marijuana Legalization
item.media:description: A fully grown marijuana plant at SLOgrown Genetics in the coastal mountain range of San Luis Obispo, Calif.
item.description: A New York Times correspondent who has covered the legalization of marijuana in California offers some suggestions on what Canadians may expect.
item.dc:creator: THOMAS FULLER

item.title: Jamal Khashoggi’s Disappearance: What We Know and Don’t Know
item.media:description: Saudi officials arrive at the Saudi consulate in Istanbul on Monday for an investigation into the Oct. 2 disappearance there of Saudi journalist Jamal Khashoggi.
item.description: The confusing case of the Saudi journalist has set off an international diplomatic storm and raised important questions, including some that cannot be answered yet.
item.dc:creator: DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK

item.title: Hailed as a Hero, Executed as a Spy, and Exonerated Decades Later
item.media:description: South Korean soldiers at the Demilitarized Zone in Panmunjom, a so-called truce village that straddles the border with North Korea.
item.description: Lee Soo-keun escaped to South Korea from the North through a hail of bullets in 1967, only to be hanged as a spy two years later. Almost 50 years later, his name has been cleared.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: Kenyans Say Chinese Investment Brings Racism and Discrimination
item.media:description: Richard Ochieng’, 26, at his home in Nairobi, Kenya. His Chinese boss called him and other Kenyans monkeys.
item.media:credit: Andrew Renneisen for The New York Times
item.description: Episodes involving discriminatory behavior by the region’s growing Chinese work force have unsettled many Kenyans, particularly at a time when their government seeks closer ties with China.
item.dc:creator: JOSEPH GOLDSTEIN

item.title: Prince Harry and Meghan Markle Announce She’s Pregnant
item.media:description: Meghan Markle and Prince Harry on their wedding day at Windsor Castle, England, in May.
item.description: The news came as the couple were beginning a tour of Australia and the South Pacific. The child is expected in the spring of 2019, Kensington Palace said.
item.dc:creator: ILIANA MAGRA and DANIEL VICTOR

item.title: France Dispatch: At World’s Largest Food Market, a Sip of Wine After a Night of Butchery
item.media:description: By the time the sun rises, workers at the Rungis food market outside Paris have consumed nearly 3,000 coffees at Le Saint Hubert cafe. Some prefer stronger drinks.
item.media:credit: Andrea Mantovani for The New York Times
item.description: Rungis, a wholesale food market bigger than Monaco, is beloved in culinary circles, but this “working-class place” is unknown to most visitors to Paris.
item.dc:creator: LIZ ALDERMAN

item.title: For Khashoggi, a Tangled Mix of Royal Service and Islamist Sympathies
item.media:description: The Saudi Consulate in Istanbul on Saturday. Jamal Khashoggi was last seen entering the building on Oct. 2.
item.description: Jamal Khashoggi had both an affinity for Islamist political movements and close ties to the Saudi royal family — until they were cut by a new crown prince.
item.dc:creator: BEN HUBBARD and DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK

item.title: Brexit Talks Fail to Break Deadlock Over Deal
item.media:description: The European Union’s chief Brexit negotiator, Michel Barnier, in Rome last week.
item.description: Critical issues remain unresolved despite “intense efforts,” said the E.U.’s negotiator. Both sides are hoping for a breakthrough this week.
item.dc:creator: STEPHEN CASTLE

item.title: Saudi Arabia and U.S. Clash Over Khashoggi Case
item.media:description: President Trump discussing weapons sales at a meeting with Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman in the Oval Office in March.
item.description: President Trump vowed “severe punishment” if the Saudis were behind a dissident’s disappearance. The Saudis said they would “respond with greater action.”
item.dc:creator: DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK

item.title: Kidnapped Aid Workers in Nigeria May Have Just Hours Before Being Killed
item.media:description: The body of one of three aid workers killed in March during an attack in the Nigerian town of Rann, at Maiduguri Airport.
item.description: A Boko Haram faction has said that by Oct. 16 it will kill an aid worker abducted as part of an attack on a military installation in March.
item.dc:creator: EMMANUEL AKINWOTU
item.category: International Committee of the Red Cross

item.title: Trump Embraces Foreign Aid to Counter China’s Global Influence
item.media:description: Workers at the One Galle Face project, which is financed by a Chinese company, in Colombo, Sri Lanka. President Trump created a new foreign aid agency to counter China’s worldwide influence.
item.description: The move is a significant reversal for the president. A new agency will provide $60 billion in financing aimed at blocking Beijing’s ambitions.
item.dc:creator: GLENN THRUSH
item.category: United States Agency for International Development

item.title: Liberal Greens and Far Right Make Bavarian Election Gains
item.media:description: Katharina Schulze, right, and Ludwig Hartmann, the co-lead candidates of the Greens, on Sunday at the Bavarian Parliament in Munich.
item.description: The far-right Alternative for Germany will enter the Bavarian Parliament for the first time. But the Greens, who favor migration, were the big winners in the election.
item.dc:creator: KATRIN BENNHOLD
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis

item.title: Canadians Already Smoke a Lot of Pot. Now It’s About to Become Legal.
item.media:description: A vendor showing off his products during a pop-up cannabis market in Hamilton, Ontario, last month.
item.media:credit: Tara Walton for The New York Times
item.description: More than 40 percent of Canadians have tried marijuana. How will legal pot change the culture of Canada, a country known for politeness, maple syrup, hockey and, perhaps soon, high-grade bud?
item.dc:creator: CATHERINE PORTER

item.title: Indian Minister at Center of #MeToo Case Calls Abuse Accusations ‘Wild and Baseless’
item.media:description: M. J. Akbar at his home in New Delhi on Sunday. He said he would take legal action against the women who had made the accusations.
item.description: M. J. Akbar, a high-ranking lawmaker at the Ministry of External Affairs, said he would take legal action against the women who had made the accusations.
item.dc:creator: REUTERS

item.title: Archbishop Óscar Romero and Pope Paul VI Are Made Saints
item.media:description: Catholics in San Salvador watched a televised screening on Sunday of the canonization ceremony of Archbishop Óscar Romero.
item.description: Pope Francis canonized the Salvadoran archbishop killed in 1980 by a right-wing death squad and the pope credited with leading the modernization of the church.
item.dc:creator: ELISABETTA POVOLEDO

item.title: Q. & A.: Val McDermid on What It’s Like Judging the Man Booker Prize
item.media:description: “On Oct. 17, I’m going to sit down and read a book I have no obligation to read,” said Val McDermid, one of five 2018 Man Booker Prize judges.
item.media:credit: Robert Ormerod for The New York Times
item.description: She read 171 books for the prestigious literary prize. “On Oct. 17, I’m going to sit down and read a book I have no obligation to read,” she said.
item.dc:creator: ALEX MARSHALL

item.title: At Least 22 Migrants Killed in Truck Crash in Turkey
item.media:description: Forensics experts examining the wreckage in Izmir, Turkey, on Sunday.
item.description: The vehicle, which had been traveling from Aydin to Izmir, was said to have veered off the road, crashed through a barrier and toppled from a highway.
item.dc:creator: THE NEW YORK TIMES
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis

item.title: British Man Pleads Guilty to Sending ‘Punish a Muslim Day’ Letters
item.media:description: Home Secretary Sajid Javid, center, with Labour’s leader, Jeremy Corbyn, third from right, marked the one-year anniversary of an attack near a Finsbury Park mosque in London in June. Mr. Javid was among those who received one of the racist letters.
item.media:credit: Dominic Lipinski/Press Association, via Associated Press
item.description: The police said that David Parnham, 35, had waged a two-year campaign of terror that included mailing packages containing suspicious substances.
item.dc:creator: YONETTE JOSEPH

item.title: Indonesia Dispatch: Their Land Defiled, Forest People Swap Flower Worship for Quran and Concrete
item.media:description: Temenggung Tarip with his wife, Putri Tija Sanggul, with their grandchildren, outside their concrete house in Jambi Province, Indonesia.
item.media:credit: Kemal Jufri for The New York Times
item.description: Indigenous forest people of the Indonesian island of Sumatra have been pushed from their land and away from their gods by timber, rubber, paper and palm oil plantations. Many have converted to Islam.
item.dc:creator: HANNAH BEECH
